title: Chrysosplenium
text:
Chrysosplenium (golden saxifrage or golden-saxifrage) is a genus of 57 species of <a href="flowering%20plant">flowering plant</a>s in the family <a href="Saxifragaceae">Saxifragaceae</a>. Species can be found throughout the arctic and northern temperate parts of the Northern Hemisphere, with the highest species diversity in eastern <a href="Asia">Asia</a>; two species are found disjunctly in <a href="South%20America">South America</a>.
They are soft <a href="herbaceous">herbaceous</a> <a href="perennial%20plant">perennial plant</a>s growing to 20 centimeters tall, typically growing in wet, shady locations in forests. The <a href="leaf">leaves</a> are rounded, palmately veined, with a lobed margin; they may be arranged either alternately or opposite, depending on the species. The <a href="flower">flower</a>s are small, yellow or yellowish-green, with four petals; they are produced in small clusters at the apex of the shoots surrounded by leafy bracts. Most of the growth and flowering is in early spring, when more light is available under <a href="deciduous">deciduous</a> trees.
Culinary uses.
The leaves and stems of golden saxifrage ("<a href="Chrysosplenium%20alternifolium">C. alternifolium</a>" and "<a href="Chrysosplenium%20oppositifolium">C. oppositifolium</a>") can be eaten in salads or as cooked greens.
